epidemiology: Affects ~20% of adults in Western countries. Risk increases with obesity, smoking, and pregnancy.

emergency_markers: Severe chest pain mimicking cardiac origin

supportive: Lifestyle modification (diet, weight loss, head elevation)

treatment_protocol: Trial PPI → Confirm with pH or endoscopy → Long-term management or surgery

epidemiology: Common worldwide. H. pylori and NSAID use are major causes. Affects ~5-10% of the population.
treatment_protocol: Endoscopy → PPI → Triple therapy if H. pylori+

epidemiology: Incidence 5–80 per 100,000. Common causes include gallstones and alcohol.

timeline.symptom: Severe epigastric pain radiating to back

treatment_protocol: Confirm with labs/imaging → Supportive care → Address cause

epidemiology: Most commonly due to chronic alcohol abuse. Prevalence: ~50 per 100,000 in developed nations.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose imaging/enzymes → Symptomatic support → Treat cause

epidemiology: Affects ~1 in 400 in Western countries. Onset usually between ages 15–30.
treatment_protocol: Confirm biopsy → Medications based on severity → Surgery if refractory

epidemiology: Prevalence ~150 per 100,000. Onset usually 15–30 years. Affects any GI segment, commonly ileum.
treatment_protocol: Biopsy confirmation → Medical therapy escalation → Surgery for refractory cases

epidemiology: Affects 10–20% of the population. More common in females and young adults.

emergency_markers: None typically; red flags suggest another cause

treatment_protocol: Exclude organic causes → Symptom-guided therapy

epidemiology: Prevalence ~1%. Strong association with HLA-DQ2/8. Often undiagnosed or misdiagnosed.
treatment_protocol: Serology → Biopsy → Gluten-free diet

epidemiology: Chronic infection affects ~300 million people globally. High endemicity in Sub-Saharan Africa and Asia.
treatment_protocol: Determine phase → Antiviral if needed → Monitor for HCC

epidemiology: Affects ~70 million globally. Leading cause of liver transplantation in developed nations.
treatment_protocol: Confirm active infection → Genotype → Treat with DAAs

epidemiology: Prevalence ~25% worldwide. Strongly linked to obesity, diabetes, and metabolic syndrome.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose with imaging → Exclude other causes → Lifestyle intervention

epidemiology: 8th most common cancer worldwide. Squamous cell carcinoma common in developing countries; adenocarcinoma in the West.
treatment_protocol: Endoscopy → Staging → Multimodal therapy

epidemiology: 5th most common cancer globally. Incidence higher in East Asia, Eastern Europe, and South America.
treatment_protocol: Endoscopy biopsy → Staging → Surgery ± chemo

epidemiology: Rare. Prevalence ~10 per 100,000. Strong association with ulcerative colitis (~80%).
treatment_protocol: MRCP diagnosis → Supportive care → Transplant if advanced

epidemiology: More common in middle-aged women. Prevalence ~20–40 per 100,000.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose AMA+ → Start UDCA → Monitor liver function

epidemiology: Rare. Incidence ~1 per 100,000/year. Typically presents in 30–60 years of age.

additional: Upper endoscopy to rule out malignancy

treatment_protocol: Manometry diagnosis → Endoscopic/surgical intervention

epidemiology: Prevalence increases with age. Affects ~50% of those >60 years old in Western populations.
treatment_protocol: CT confirmation → Antibiotics → Surgery if recurrent/severe

epidemiology: Lifetime risk ~7%. Most common surgical emergency in young adults.
treatment_protocol: Clinical suspicion → Imaging → Surgery

epidemiology: Affects 4–5% of the population. Risk increases with age, constipation, pregnancy.
treatment_protocol: Lifestyle → Office procedure → Surgery if severe

epidemiology: Common cause of anal pain. Affects all ages, especially young adults.
treatment_protocol: Conservative → Medical → Surgery if chronic

epidemiology: Common in adults. Often due to obstruction of anal glands.

additional: MRI or ultrasound for deep abscesses

treatment_protocol: Clinical exam → Prompt drainage → Antibiotics if systemic signs

epidemiology: Incidence highest in North America and Europe. Affects both genders, often onset in teens/20s.
treatment_protocol: Induction → Maintenance → Surgery for complications

epidemiology: More common in developed countries. Peaks in 20s and 60s.
treatment_protocol: Assess severity → Medical therapy → Surgery if needed

epidemiology: Common globally. Major causes: H. pylori infection, NSAID use.
treatment_protocol: Test for H. pylori → PPI ± triple therapy

epidemiology: Most common healthcare-associated infection in the U.S. Risk increases with antibiotic use and hospitalization.
treatment_protocol: Confirm infection → Start appropriate antibiotics → Monitor for complications

epidemiology: Occurs after significant surgical resection of small intestine. Rare but serious malabsorptive condition.
treatment_protocol: Nutritional assessment → Supportive care → Transplant evaluation if refractory

epidemiology: Affects ~1% of the population globally. More common in individuals of European descent.
treatment_protocol: Serology → Biopsy → Gluten-free diet

epidemiology: Rare but often fatal. Occurs more commonly in elderly or patients with atrial fibrillation.

timeline.symptom: Severe abdominal pain out of proportion to exam

treatment_protocol: Urgent imaging → Resuscitation → Surgery

epidemiology: Affects 10–15% of the global population. More common in females and young adults.

additional: Exclude red flags: CBC, colonoscopy if needed

treatment_protocol: Clinical diagnosis → Diet/lifestyle → Targeted therapy

epidemiology: 12th most common cancer worldwide, but 7th leading cause of cancer deaths. Poor prognosis.
treatment_protocol: Imaging → Resectability → Surgery ± Chemo

epidemiology: More common in males. Chronic alcohol abuse is the leading cause.
treatment_protocol: Supportive → Address etiology → Surgery if refractory

epidemiology: 8th most common cancer worldwide; more common in men. Risk factors differ by histological type (SCC vs. adenocarcinoma).
treatment_protocol: Endoscopy → Staging → Surgery ± Chemoradiation

epidemiology: Seen in ~10% of chronic GERD patients. Predisposes to adenocarcinoma of the esophagus.

definitive: Endoscopic ablation or esophagectomy for dysplasia

treatment_protocol: Endoscopy → Surveillance or Ablation

epidemiology: Rare. More common in females. Associated with other autoimmune diseases.
treatment_protocol: Biopsy → Steroids ± Azathioprine

epidemiology: More common in men and those with ulcerative colitis. Rare chronic cholestatic liver disease.
treatment_protocol: MRCP → Monitor → Transplant if decompensated

epidemiology: Autoimmune disease, more common in middle-aged women. Prevalence is 1 in 1000 women over age 40.
treatment_protocol: Serology → Start UDCA → Monitor

epidemiology: Most commonly due to liver cirrhosis. Seen in advanced liver disease, malignancies, and heart failure.
treatment_protocol: Assess cause → Diuretics ± Paracentesis → Treat etiology

epidemiology: Occurs in ~10–30% of cirrhotic patients with ascites. Medical emergency.
treatment_protocol: Diagnosis → Antibiotics + Albumin → Monitor response

epidemiology: Serious complication of advanced liver disease. Functional renal failure without structural damage.

emergency_markers: Rapid rise in creatinine in cirrhotic patient

treatment_protocol: Rule out other causes → Terlipressin + Albumin → Transplant

epidemiology: Most common chronic liver disease worldwide. Strongly associated with metabolic syndrome.
treatment_protocol: Lifestyle → Monitor LFTs → Treat NASH if present

epidemiology: Seen in advanced cirrhosis. Triggered by GI bleeding, infection, constipation, electrolyte imbalance.
treatment_protocol: Identify trigger → Lactulose ± Rifaximin → Monitor mental status

epidemiology: Rare autosomal recessive disorder. Onset typically in adolescence or early adulthood.

emergency_markers: Acute liver failure with Coombs-negative hemolytic anemia

treatment_protocol: Diagnosis → Chelation ± Zinc → Monitor

epidemiology: Common inherited metabolic disorder in Caucasians. Men > women due to menstruation protecting women.
treatment_protocol: Screen → Confirm → Phlebotomy → Monitor

epidemiology: Final common pathway of many chronic liver diseases. Leading causes include hepatitis B/C and alcohol.
treatment_protocol: Diagnose → Stage → Treat cause → Manage complications

epidemiology: Most common primary liver cancer. Common in HBV, HCV, cirrhosis. Higher in sub-Saharan Africa and Asia.
treatment_protocol: Surveillance → Imaging/AFP → Treatment per BCLC stage

epidemiology: Rare cancer of the bile ducts. Increased incidence with PSC, liver flukes, and biliary anomalies.
treatment_protocol: Imaging → Staging → Surgery or Palliative

epidemiology: Rare but life-threatening. Often affects elderly patients with atrial fibrillation or atherosclerosis.

emergency_markers: Pain out of proportion to physical findings

treatment_protocol: Urgent CTA → Surgery → Resect necrotic bowel

epidemiology: Rare. Usually affects elderly with atherosclerosis. Often involves >2 major mesenteric arteries.
treatment_protocol: CTA → Revascularization → Monitor

epidemiology: Common in endemic regions. Often involves the ileocecal area. Can mimic Crohn’s disease.

emergency_markers: Acute abdomen in known TB case

treatment_protocol: Colonoscopy → Confirm TB → ATT

epidemiology: Occurs after major bowel resection. Associated with malnutrition and electrolyte imbalance.
treatment_protocol: Assess extent → Nutritional rehab ± TPN → Long-term support

epidemiology: Most common form of intestinal ischemia. Typically affects elderly. Often transient and self-limited.
treatment_protocol: CT → Colonoscopy → Supportive ± Surgery

epidemiology: Common worldwide. Associated with H. pylori infection and NSAID use.

important: H. pylori testing (urea breath test or biopsy)

treatment_protocol: Endoscopy → H. pylori test → PPI ± eradication

epidemiology: Rare cause of recurrent peptic ulcers due to gastrin-secreting tumor (gastrinoma).
treatment_protocol: Elevated gastrin → Imaging → Surgery or medical therapy

epidemiology: Rare in adults. Often due to chronic PUD or malignancy. More common in infants.
treatment_protocol: Correct fluids/electrolytes → Endoscopy ± Surgery

epidemiology: Common in diabetics. Also seen post-surgery and with some medications (opioids, anticholinergics).
treatment_protocol: Diagnosis → Prokinetics → Supportive care

epidemiology: Collection of indigestible material in stomach. Risk increased in gastroparesis, post-surgery.
treatment_protocol: Diagnosis → Endoscopic management → Treat cause

epidemiology: Chronic immune-mediated esophageal condition. More common in young males with allergic conditions.
treatment_protocol: Endoscopy + biopsy → Dietary or medical therapy → Monitor

epidemiology: Commonly caused by chronic GERD or corrosive ingestion. Can also follow radiation or surgery.
treatment_protocol: Endoscopy → Dilation + PPI → Monitor

epidemiology: Metaplastic change of esophageal epithelium due to chronic GERD. Risk factor for esophageal adenocarcinoma.

emergency_markers: Sudden worsening of symptoms suggesting cancer

treatment_protocol: Endoscopy → Biopsy → Surveillance or Ablation

epidemiology: Rare esophageal motility disorder characterized by impaired LES relaxation and absent peristalsis.

additional: Upper endoscopy to rule out malignancy

treatment_protocol: Diagnosis → Dilation or surgery → Follow-up

epidemiology: Two main types: squamous cell carcinoma (upper 2/3) and adenocarcinoma (lower 1/3, often in Barrett’s).
treatment_protocol: Diagnosis → Staging → Multimodal therapy

epidemiology: Common cause of upper GI bleeding. Often seen after forceful vomiting or retching, especially in alcoholics.
treatment_protocol: Endoscopy → Conservative/Endoscopic control → Monitor

epidemiology: Rare but fatal. Esophageal rupture due to forceful vomiting. Common in middle-aged males with alcohol abuse.

emergency_markers: Acute chest pain after vomiting with subcutaneous crepitus

treatment_protocol: Imaging → Surgery ± Endoscopic → ICU care

epidemiology: Rare mesenchymal tumor of GI tract. Common in stomach and small intestine. Often occurs in adults > 40.
treatment_protocol: Imaging → Biopsy → Resection or TKI therapy

epidemiology: Common emergency. Includes peptic ulcer, gastritis, and Mallory-Weiss tear. Accounts for >80% of UGIB cases.
treatment_protocol: Stabilize → Endoscopy → Treat source

epidemiology: Rare finding of gas within bowel wall. May be benign or life-threatening. Associated with COPD, ischemia, or obstruction.

emergency_markers: Signs of peritonitis or systemic instability

treatment_protocol: Assess cause → Monitor or Surgery → Treat underlying issue

epidemiology: Occurs mainly in elderly patients with cardiovascular disease. Can be arterial (embolic or thrombotic) or venous.

timeline.symptom: Sudden severe abdominal pain out of proportion to physical findings

treatment_protocol: CT angiography → Resuscitate → Surgery or endovascular intervention

epidemiology: Common in children and adolescents. Often follows viral infection or Yersinia enterocolitica.
treatment_protocol: Ultrasound → Supportive care → Antibiotics if needed

epidemiology: Autoimmune disorder triggered by gluten. Common in Northern Europeans. Affects ~1% of the population.
treatment_protocol: Serology → Biopsy → Gluten-free diet

epidemiology: Rare multisystem infection caused by Tropheryma whipplei. Affects middle-aged white males most commonly.

definitive: IV ceftriaxone then long-term oral TMP-SMX

treatment_protocol: Biopsy → IV antibiotics → Oral maintenance therapy

epidemiology: Most common form of intestinal ischemia. Seen in elderly with vascular disease or hypotensive episodes.

emergency_markers: Signs of peritonitis or systemic sepsis

definitive: Surgical resection if infarction or perforation

treatment_protocol: Imaging → Supportive care → Surgery if needed

epidemiology: Congenital absence of ganglion cells in the distal colon, leading to functional obstruction. More common in males.

timeline.symptom: Failure to pass meconium in first 48 hours

treatment_protocol: Diagnosis → Bowel decompression → Surgery

epidemiology: Occurs after surgical resection of a significant portion of the small intestine. Leads to malabsorption and nutrient deficiency.
treatment_protocol: Nutritional assessment → Support → Surgery if needed

epidemiology: Common surgical emergency. Causes include adhesions, hernias, tumors, and strictures.
treatment_protocol: Imaging → Conservative → Surgery if needed

epidemiology: Most common abdominal emergency in children under 2 years. Telescoping of one bowel segment into another.

emergency_markers: Signs of bowel necrosis or peritonitis

treatment_protocol: Ultrasound → Enema reduction → Surgery if needed

epidemiology: Twisting of bowel around mesentery. Sigmoid volvulus most common in elderly; midgut volvulus more common in infants.
treatment_protocol: Imaging → Decompression → Surgery if required
